title: 114_hr6172
content: The "Campus Fire Safety Education Act of 2016" aims to provide fire safety education to students at higher education institutions. The Act defines key terms such as "Administrator," "Eligible entity," and "Fire safety education program." The curr_chunk defines "institution of higher education" and "Secretary" as per specific legislation. Establishment of the Campus Fire Safety Education Competitive Grant Program. The Secretary, in consultation with the Administrator, will establish a grant program to award grants to eligible entities for fire safety education programs at higher education institutions. Priority will be given to entities planning to improve fire safety education. The grant program aims to support fire safety education programs for students with disabilities, with grants awarded for up to a 2-year period and a maximum amount of $250,000 per fiscal year. Eligible entities must provide matching funds to receive the grant. Entities receiving assistance under this Act must provide non-Federal matching funds of at least 25% of the activity costs, which can be in cash or in kind. Funds from this Act should supplement, not replace, other Federal, State, or private funds for fire safety education programs. SEC. 5. REQUIRED USES OF FUNDS. An eligible entity receiving a grant under this Act must use the funds to implement a fire safety education program for all students, including those living on and off-campus. The program should involve outreach to students twice a year and provide fire safety information upon request. The fire safety education program funded by the grant includes minimum instruction on fire behavior, mechanisms of fire injury, common ignition scenarios, fire safety systems, alarms, extinguishers, means of egress, prevention techniques, and actions to take in case of a fire. The fire safety education program funded by the grant includes instruction on fire behavior, fire injury mechanisms, ignition scenarios, safety systems, alarms, extinguishers, egress, prevention techniques, and actions in case of a fire. Evaluations must be conducted on the program's effectiveness in increasing awareness or improving fire safety behavior, with a report submitted to the Secretary. The section on reports requires evaluations of the fire safety education program's effectiveness to be conducted and a report to be submitted to the Secretary. The Secretary must report annually to Congress on the number and types of eligible entities receiving assistance, fire safety education programs, and any other relevant information to evaluate the effectiveness of the program in improving fire safety knowledge among college students. Additionally, a best practices report will be published using this information. A report of best practices for fire safety education programs will be published for institutions of higher education and interested parties. Authorization of appropriations for this Act includes $15,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2017 to 2021.
